title: Decentralized Centralization: The Blockchain Proliferation Paradox
subtitle: Why Ten Years After Steemit There Are Not 200 Social Media Blockchains, Why Your Church Should Have a Cryptocurrency, And How Federated Hubs Create True Decentralization
author: Rev. Ryan Sasha-Shai Van Kush / Van Kush Family Research Institute

abstract.central_thesis: True decentralization requires many centralized hubs - just as the federal system of the United States creates genuine distributed power through strong state governments, blockchain adoption requires strong local implementations (churches, bars, restaurants, venues, libraries, municipal governments) each with their own currencies, mining opportunities, and community governance, all connected through federated exchange with the broader cryptocurrency ecosystem.
abstract.core_argument: Rather than asking ordinary people to convert their dollars directly into Bitcoin, we should encourage the proliferation of thousands of localized, community-specific blockchains that then trade against Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies on decentralized exchanges.
abstract.historical_context: The author proposed 'Bitcointown' on Bitcointalk.org in 2013, traced the emergence of corporate crypto-towns (Bud Light's Whatever USA), celebrity crypto-cities (Akon City - cancelled), and nation-state adoption (El Salvador's Bitcoin City - unbuilt).
abstract.paradox: Despite the proof-of-concept provided by Steemit and Graphene blockchain in 2016, we do not have hundreds of social media platforms with their own witness systems and reward tokens ten years later.

rolltitup_origins.problem_discovered: Troubling absence of leadership - Keith Stroup and NORML existed, but no real religious authority building legal frameworks

content_areas: Revolutionary history (Black Panther movement, dollar bill symbolism)
youtube_expansion.dollar_bill_research: Explored the owl in the corner, Eye of Providence, unfinished pyramid - not attacking Masons, but investigating what these symbols meant and why they were placed there

devtome_devcoin.devcoin_description: One of the first 'ethical cryptocurrencies' - distributing 90% of newly minted coins to open source developers and Creative Commons writers rather than miners
devtome_devcoin.author_profile_quote: A Writer, Bitcoin/Devcoin enthusiast, and Film Maker as well as an advocate for Marijuana, Personal liberties and the secession of Texas
devtome_devcoin.significance: Proof of concept that people would create substantial content for crypto rewards years before Steemit existed

devcoin_expansion_proposals.dev_for_humanity: Free apartments funded by mining servers
devcoin_expansion_proposals.devatm: Machines accepting cash for Devcoins on USB drives
devcoin_expansion_proposals.devisland: A rented island for Devcoin events
devcoin_expansion_proposals.anticipation: These proposals anticipated by years the crypto-cities and blockchain-powered communities that would later be attempted by celebrities and governments

bitcointown_proposal.concept: A physical community organized around cryptocurrency adoption - local merchants accept Bitcoin, residents mine, town serves as demonstration project for blockchain-based governance and commerce
bitcointown_proposal.corporate_mirrors_idea: Cryptocurrency brands that would back their coins with real goods and services
bitcointown_proposal.ban_reason: Too involved, but not being a developer or a nerd

lawsuit.allegation: Sherman Act violations - forum operated as illegal monopoly over cryptocurrency development access
lawsuit.outcome: Dismissed when $400 filing fee went unpaid
lawsuit.documentation: iPleaders.com documented as 'the first case of blockchain and antitrust'

bud_light_whatever_usa.concept: Temporarily transformed into a branded town with 'Mayor of Whatever USA' character in bright blue suit riding blue horse
bud_light_whatever_usa.significance: Not cryptocurrency-based, but concept of temporary branded community with own governance and identity directly paralleled Bitcointown proposal

akon_city.description: 'Real-life Wakanda' in Senegal powered by Akoin cryptocurrency
akon_city.termination: July 2025 - Senegal officially terminated after seven years of zero construction progress
akon_city.akoin_value: Fallen to $0.003 and delisted from exchanges

subsequent_adoptions.pattern_identified: Ideas for cryptocurrency communities emerged from grassroots enthusiasts, were either suppressed or ignored by developer-centric establishment, and then were adopted (poorly) by corporations and celebrities who lacked authentic community connection

steemit_proof_of_concept.july_4_2016_event: $1.3 million worth of stored-up STEEM rewards released to early participants
revolutionary_concepts: Content creators earn cryptocurrency for posts and comments
Voters (curators) earn for identifying quality content
Witnesses (Graphene equivalent of miners) validate transactions through Delegated Proof of Stake
Platform handles transaction volume of active social media site
Technology is open source and replicable
steemit_proof_of_concept.luke_stokes_quote_1: Through nothing short of a small miracle we have almost no viable competition
steemit_proof_of_concept.luke_stokes_quote_2: Steemit is built using a very advanced blockchain database technology called Graphene 2.0 which can scale incredibly well

powered_projects: HIVE (forked from STEEM after corporate conflicts)
graphene_ecosystem.status: Technology proven, open source, available for anyone to fork and modify

the_missing_200_blockchains.question: Where are the Twitter clones with witness systems? Where are the Facebook alternatives with reward tokens? Where are the forum platforms where moderation is decentralized and content cannot be censored by corporate policy changes?

technical_complexity.problem: Despite being open source, deploying and maintaining a Graphene-based blockchain requires significant technical expertise
technical_complexity.cultural_factor: Cypherpunk culture of cryptocurrency development prioritizes technical purity over accessibility
technical_complexity.documentation: Assumes developer knowledge - community not structured to help non-technical people launch platforms

witness_economics.incentive_problem: Witnesses need share of newly minted tokens
witness_economics.chicken_egg_problem: Need users for token value, need witnesses for operation, witnesses need token value for incentive

network_effects.problem: Social media platforms derive value from user networks
network_effects.new_platform_challenge: Starts with zero network value - users must be convinced to invest time and identity in unproven platform

regulatory_uncertainty.issue: Launching a tradeable token raises securities law questions
regulatory_uncertainty.effect: Many potential platform creators deterred by legal risk

cultural_gatekeeping.pattern: Cryptocurrency community historically hostile to non-developer participation
cultural_gatekeeping.example: Author's experience - forums and development resources controlled by insiders who ban 'outsiders' who are 'too involved'
cultural_gatekeeping.result: Creates monoculture where innovation is stifled

gas_fee_problem.historical_issue: During peak congestion periods in 2021, simple transactions could cost $50-100 or more in 'gas fees'
gas_fee_problem.made_unsuitable_for: Small transactions, community tokens, everyday commerce

dencun_upgrade_eip_4844.effect: Reduced Layer 2 data posting costs by 50-90%

2025_improvements.layer_2_adoption: Networks like Arbitrum, Optimism, and Base now handle over 58% of Ethereum transaction volume with fees often under $0.01

community_discussion_centralization.concept: A church with its own blockchain has a native forum for community discussion
community_discussion_centralization.governance: Decisions about token distribution, witness elections, and protocol changes become community governance decisions
community_discussion_centralization.permanence: Discussion happens on-chain, permanently recorded, with voting weighted by community participation
community_discussion_centralization.distinction: Fundamentally different from using someone else's platform

economic_velocity.devcoin_observation: When iGotSpots started trading precious metals directly for DevCoin, the token's economic health improved dramatically
economic_velocity.steem_hive_problem: When they lacked such direct commodity trading, they suffered
economic_velocity.key_insight: A local currency that can be directly exchanged for goods and services of its issuing community (food, drinks, services) has inherent velocity that purely speculative tokens lack

mining_as_participation.current_problem: Requiring people to buy Bitcoin with dollars
mining_as_participation.solution: Community chain allows members to earn tokens through participation
mining_as_participation.mining_forms: Running a node, volunteer work, content creation, event attendance, other forms of community contribution

speed_and_cost_optimization.principle: Community chain can be optimized for its specific use case
speed_and_cost_optimization.bar_example: Doesn't need Bitcoin's security guarantees - needs fast, cheap transactions for tab management
speed_and_cost_optimization.church_example: Doesn't need global consensus - needs transparent accounting for tithes and disbursements
speed_and_cost_optimization.conclusion: Local optimization is impossible on global chains

part_4_mit_centralization.title: MIT and the Centralization of Decentralization

bitcoin_foundation_collapse.mit_response: Digital Currency Initiative (DCI) stepped in, providing institutional home for core developers Gavin Andresen, Cory Fields, and Wladimir van der Laan

mit_dci_goals.stated_purpose: To provide neutral, academic stewardship for Bitcoin development, to 'reduce bottlenecks in the development ecosystem which might lead to centralization'
mit_dci_goals.irony: An elite academic institution became the central point of coordination for a technology designed to have no central point

mit_dci_acknowledgment.quote_1: As the use of Bitcoin grows, and as it becomes more deeply embedded into our societies, the security of the network must grow and strengthen alongside it. Yet, as a common good, there is no one single Bitcoin protector or guardian to take on this formidable task.
mit_dci_acknowledgment.quote_2: Even in decentralized systems like Bitcoin, there has been a natural market consolidation in the form of large mining pools. This type of consolidation into a few super-participants might be inevitable due to economies of scale.
mit_dci_acknowledgment.conclusion_drawn: We are increasingly persuaded that this isn't necessarily a bad thing, and that a more realistic goal might be the development of a robust, competitive marketplace

paradox_of_neutral_leadership.mit_position: Accept that centralization happens, and focus on making it benevolent
paradox_of_neutral_leadership.critique: Reasonable position for an institution like MIT, which is itself a centralized authority. But represents a fundamental departure from the cypherpunk vision of trustless systems.

alternative_resolution.proposal: Rather than accepting Bitcoin will be governed by a few super-participants coordinated through MIT, embrace the multiplication of centralized hubs that connect in a decentralized manner

us_federal_analogy.state_authority: Each state is a centralized authority within its borders - governor, legislature, courts, enforcement mechanisms
us_federal_analogy.collective_decentralization: 50 states together create genuine decentralization of power - no single state can dominate the others
us_federal_analogy.federal_framework: Provides framework for interstate commerce and dispute resolution, but substantive governance happens at state and local level

blockchain_application.church_example: A church with its own blockchain is centralized within its community but decentralized relative to other churches
blockchain_application.city_example: A city with its own token is centralized within its boundaries but decentralized relative to other cities
blockchain_application.connection_method: Local authorities connect through exchange mechanisms - trading tokens against Bitcoin, Ethereum, HIVE, and each other - creating genuine distributed power

features: Tithes and offerings recorded on-chain with full transparency
Members can see how funds are allocated
Community discusses and votes on major expenditures
churches_religious_organizations.significance: Not merely financial - spiritual accountability made manifest in code

bars_restaurants.economic_feature: Because food perishes, there is natural economic pressure to keep tokens circulating - solving the 'hodling' problem that makes some cryptocurrencies economically inert

implementations: Concert tickets as NFTs that become collectible trading cards after the event
Venue tokens that grant priority access
Fan tokens that allow voting on setlists or opening acts
entertainment_venues.status: Technology exists; implementation requires only will

local_governments.uses: Municipal tokens for parking, transit, library fines, and permits
local_governments.earning_mechanism: Citizens earn tokens through civic participation
local_governments.potential: Property taxes could be payable in local tokens acquired through community service

libraries.token_rewards_for: Book returns, volunteer hours, program attendance, content contribution
libraries.governance: Library governance could become genuinely democratic through token-weighted voting

wifi_cafes_coworking_spaces.original_vision: Making physical locations into mining hubs
wifi_cafes_coworking_spaces.mechanism: Cafe runs a node, forms mining pools with other cafes, distributes tokens to customers
wifi_cafes_coworking_spaces.economics: Cafe's internet connection generates revenue; customers' presence validates transactions

exchange_ecosystem_how_it_works.key_insight: No one should be asked to spend USD directly on Bitcoin as their first cryptocurrency experience

step_1.action: Person earns ChurchCoin by volunteering, or BarToken by frequent patronage, or CityScript by civic participation
step_1.result: Cryptocurrency enters their life through activity they were already doing

step_2.action: They learn to use a wallet, check balances, and make transactions in a low-stakes environment
step_2.utility: Tokens have direct utility (redeem for coffee, get priority seating, vote on church decisions)

step_3.action: They discover that their local token can be traded on decentralized exchanges for other tokens - including Bitcoin and Ethereum
step_3.example: $50 worth of BarToken can become $50 worth of ETH

step_4.result: They now understand cryptocurrency through experience rather than speculation
step_4.choices: May choose to hold ETH or BTC, or prefer local tokens, or both
step_4.nature: On-ramp was natural rather than forced

step_5.community_effect: Local tokens gain legitimacy through utility and exchange value

corporate_mirror_concept.definition: Cryptocurrency implementations by legitimate businesses that back their tokens with real goods and services
corporate_mirror_concept.argument: Cryptocurrency should not be solely the province of anarchists and speculators

dominos_example.hypothetical: If Domino's Pizza launched PIZZA Token, backed by guarantee that 1,000 PIZZA could always be redeemed for a large pizza
dominos_example.effect: Token would have inherent floor value
dominos_example.activities: People could mine PIZZA, trade PIZZA, speculate on PIZZA - but underlying utility remains
dominos_example.note: Not the existing HIVE token, which came after the author proposed this concept

corporate_mirror_concept.requires: Corporations to think differently about loyalty programs
corporate_mirror_concept.instead_of: Proprietary points that expire and have restrictions
corporate_mirror_concept.issue: Blockchain tokens with real exchange value
corporate_mirror_concept.marketing_value: Being a 'crypto-forward' brand would offset the cost of redemptions
corporate_mirror_concept.ecosystem_effect: Many corporate tokens would provide the liquidity and legitimacy that cryptocurrency ecosystem currently lacks

anarchist_capture_of_cryptocurrency.reference: Companion paper 'Federalism vs. Anarchy in Terms of Blockchain'
anarchist_capture_of_cryptocurrency.cypherpunks_manifesto_1993: We the Cypherpunks are dedicated to building anonymous systems... Privacy is necessary for an open society in the electronic age.
anarchist_capture_of_cryptocurrency.ideological_effect: This capture has prevented the technology from being deployed by institutions that cypherpunks distrust: governments, corporations, and religious organizations
anarchist_capture_of_cryptocurrency.developer_resistance: Community has actively resisted mainstream adoption, preferring ideological purity to practical impact
anarchist_capture_of_cryptocurrency.gatekeeping_example: Author's ban from Bitcointalk - for being 'too involved, but not being a developer or a nerd' - exemplifies this. Non-technical people with community-building ideas were excluded in favor of technically proficient anarchists

igotspots_lesson.observation: DevCoin's economic health improved dramatically when iGotSpots began trading precious metals directly for the token
igotspots_lesson.mechanism: Created real-world anchor for token value - you could exchange DevCoin for gold and silver, establishing a floor
igotspots_lesson.steem_hive_problem: When they lacked similar precious metals trading, their tokens floated freely based on speculation and network effects

examples.church_token: Backed by real services (weddings, funerals, counseling) is more stable than a token backed by nothing
examples.restaurant_token: Backed by food has inherent value

igotspots_lesson.community_failure: Cryptocurrency community has largely ignored this lesson, preferring speculative model where tokens are valued purely on anticipated future adoption - creating boom-and-bust cycles

easy_deployment_tools.need: A church administrator should be able to launch ChurchCoin without learning Solidity
easy_deployment_tools.status: Templates and no-code tools exist in preliminary form but are not mature or user-friendly

federated_exchange_protocols.need: Local tokens need to be tradeable against each other and against major cryptocurrencies
federated_exchange_protocols.status: Decentralized exchanges exist but are not designed for the long tail of thousands of small community tokens

legal_frameworks.problem: SEC's hostility to tokens has chilled innovation
legal_frameworks.need: Clear guidance distinguishing utility tokens from securities
legal_frameworks.potential: Author's federal litigation for religious exemptions may provide precedent

educational_resources.need: Educational materials pitched at community organizations rather than speculators

conclusion.title: The Time Is Now
conclusion.ten_year_failure: Ten years after Steemit proved that social media could run on blockchain, we should have hundreds of competing platforms. We don't - because the technology was captured by an ideological movement that preferred purity to proliferation.

historical_pattern.2021: El Salvador announced Bitcoin City (still unbuilt)
historical_pattern.pattern: Community-based cryptocurrency adoption ideas emerge from grassroots enthusiasts, are rejected by the developer establishment, and are then poorly executed by corporations and governments that lack authentic community connection

solution.true_decentralization: Requires many centralized hubs: your church, your bar, your city, your library, your workplace
solution.each_with: Its own token, its own governance, its own community
solution.all_connected: Through federated exchange - trading against each other, against Bitcoin, against Ethereum, against HIVE

conclusion.onramp_principle: People should not be asked to spend dollars directly on Bitcoin. They should earn their first cryptocurrency through participation in communities they already belong to. The on-ramp should be natural, not forced.

technology_ready.barriers: Not technical - they are cultural, legal, and organizational
